abstract.p: Circumstances and results of tests of a three-chambered REDSOD built for attachment to a Caterpillar D9 tractor are discussed. The Caterpillar D9 tractor was chosen for its drawbar capability of 4000 lb/ft of width, bare weight of approximately 70,000 lb, and 10 ft width. Tests in straight trenching operations were performed at two sites: one in an area with a clay overburden, the other in sand. From the data presented, it is concluded that a REDSOD machine, with a 1200 ft³ min air compressor, handled by a skilled operator, can produce a 2 ft deep trench at approximately 2000 yd³ /h. The noise level is not damaging to operator or adjacent structures or personnel. The use of higher air pressures increases production rates. The recoil produced by REDSOD has no appreciable effect on production rate or tractor reliability.

ref.mixed-citation: Charles D. Wood, A. R. Nye, and Rosser B. Melton, "Experience of the Use of Fuel-Air Explosions for Controlled Earthmoving." Paper 710160 presented at SAE Automotive Engineering Congress, Detroit, January 1971.
H. L. Nichols, Jr., "Moving the Earth-The Workbook of Excavation." Chap. 11, 2nd ed. North Castle Books, 1962.
John W. Colburn, Jr., "Development of An Explosive Icebreaker." Final Report, Contract DOT-CG-12118-A, SwRI No. AR-852, January 1973.
J. W, Colburn, Jr. and R. J. Mathis, "Development of a Repetitive Explosion Device for Rock Fracturing." Final Report, Contract DAAK02-72-C-0374, SwRI No. AR-851, December 1972.
